very small cage, eating bamboo; In the village of East side of Lake Alaotra Ambatomanga, a fisherman's family kept in captivity a male individual of Bandro. The animal inside the house of this family and sometimes some family member brings him to perform a small tower in the village. On the other hand, in the village of Anororo two other families keep in captivity the same species. The first family has put three people in a small Bandro of about one square to the other family left free animals walking around their home. 

Image 110, 111, 112

These five individuals were all seized by the team DREEF and Durrell in Ambatondrazaka. And they are released into their natural habitat after conducting a proper audit their health by a veterinarian.

the lemures were normally restrained by a string, i.e. they were not kept in a cage. For food they good some kind of vegetables, cooked rice, peanuts, perhaps less fruits (bananas) in case it would have been necessary to buy it

I have never seen offspring of lemurs in captivity. Lemurs usually behaved rather tame with the close human family. In my observations kept lemurs are a regular (but not too common) phenomenon in smaller villages near to dry forst at least along the western coast line between Morondava and Mitsinjo, used as a pet for children. The use as food is difficult to assess, as it is under penalty, but it is certainly a fact.

I got the distinct impression these lemurs had been captured solely for the arrival of the South African cruise ship, though the villagers may have tried to sell them on to hotesl afterwards
The lemur was adult or subadult, tied up with cord and attached to a table at the small Malagasy-run hotely were we ate breakfast on Christmas Day. There was no food or water present.
In the garden. The mouse lemur in a cage but the red fronted lemur and ring tailed lemur and free in the garden

other_comments: Island where they are being fed bananas by tourists. They are quite aggressive, and my husband was bitten (later requiring rabies shots) and I was scratched. Bananas are not what lemurs should be eating!
captive_environment_other: Island

other_comments: They kept him tied to a post with a rope around his middle because he often tried to bite the children and the dogs. They fed him on bananas. We decided this wasn't good and we persuaded them to give him to us. We managed to get him in a basket and tie the top up and then we took him on a speed boat to the village of Mangily where there is a spiny forest which is managed that tourist pay to visit. They have a lemur sanctuary there where they keep rescued lemurs until they can be released back into the wild. They encourage the lemurs to form family groups so they can be released. They had roughly 30 ring tailed lemurs there and I suspect most of them were pets at some point. I have photos of Maki if that helps.

A medium-sized cage made of wood and chicken wire. The cage looked fairly recent (fresh looking wood, wire not rusted). Food and water were provided. Animals looked in good condition, though at least one had a rope around its waist.
The cages were in a hotel, but not being actively displayed to us (white English tourists). They were in a cage with three individuals, next to a cage containing a single ring-tailed lemur and a tortoise. We didn't approach the cages but the lemurs did not seem in any obvious distress.

lemur_purpose_money: They were kept in front of a hotel & restaurant, as an attraction for turists to enter the restaurant, but no money was specifically asked for seeing them.
other_comments: They wre kept in a small cage, maybe approx. 4 squaremeters. They were able to climb on branches within the cage.

environment_other: There were two lemurs that lived in a couple of isolated trees outside of Mahajunga by the sacred lake. I do not know if they always lived in these trees or if they were otherwise captive. We were brought there by a tourist guide.
lemur_purpose_money: We didn't pay directly to take a picture with the lemurs or anything like that, though it's possible that our tour company paid the community to visit. There were also several crocodiles in captivity.
lemur_health_details: Healthy
other_comments:
When I saw the lemurs, they were not restrained or in a cage, but there were not many trees around, and it seemed that they were habituated in that area. They may have been feeding them, or may have kept them in cages when visitors were not there. Or, perhaps they just stayed in those trees for lack of anywhere else to go. They appeared healthy.

Lemurs seemed okay with humans. They were not so habituated that they would jump on you, but they were not afraid to get relatively close.

never saw direct payements for petting lemurs (except at that dreadful place on the pangalanes, palmarium?), but is often a minor tourist attraction

there was a cage but the lemurs were out and about while we were in the restauraunt. Since this was in 2008 I am not recalling what they were fed.

lemur_health_details: It looked very healthy and well cared for and was domesticated.
other_comments:
A family from Tuliear were visiting FD and had the maki on a lead in a resturant. It was not the restuarants lemur but the family who were just eating there. It looked very healthy and well cared for and was domesticated. When challenged the family said that it was too domesticated to be released. I was surprised the resturant allowed this and I know when they later visited another hotel the hotel managed threw them out.

I was surprised when it was accepted in the restuarant - maybe because they were foriegners? Glad though when the hotel took a stance on this

lemur_health_details: In Mitsinjo, there were several Eulemur fulvus rufus females at a home in the village which were tied with rope around their waists with only a couple of feet allowance to move (no cage). They had frequent diarrhea and one female was said to be about 5 years old and she had distinct cataracts on both eyes and likely could not see very well. They were incredibly stressed and had no way to hide or get away from people, dogs, etc. The youngest one was very young, certainly no more than 6 months of age. They were being fed rice and some fruit. At a separate home there was a young, under a year, female Eulemur mongoz tied with rope around her waist which was tied to a table (no cage). She may have been available for sale but I was told she was a pet. I was encouraged to feed her a banana. There was an additional Efr juvenile
other_comments:
The above information is a combination of several trips spanning from 2008 to 2012. We were surveying lemurs in the Mitsinjo area and then conducting a follow up conservation education project a couple of years later. The people in the area knew that we were interested in the lemurs so they wanted to show them off to us which is why we were able to get so much information about them. The local NGO Asity explained that they know it is illegal but that people were not penalized in the area (at least not as of 2010) for having pet lemurs so that is why people weren't afraid to talk to us about them. An interesting fact, we used Ako Project books in our Lambas for Lemurs project in Mitsinjo and we had been given a survey by Alison and Hanta to ask the children. The children who lived in the town had almost all seen pet lemurs while the children in the bush had never seen a pet lemur. The children in town had never seen a wild lemur while the children from the bush had all seen a wild lemur. We lived in the Ft Dauphin area for 2 years and only saw the one lemur from the road by chance. I know there were others in the city, I certainly heard about more, but people there knew that it was illegal and did not want us to know. We worked in a village outside of the city as well, Ste Luce, and although we had a very strong presence there, we never saw or heard of any pet lemurs. There was a heavy researcher presence both by us and by QMM mining company and the lemurs were surveyed on a regular basis. My feelings are that a) they knew we were conservationists and thought we might report them or b) there genuinely weren't many being kept as pets. We never encountered an actual pet trade other than what we were told about in Mahajunga. All of the ones we saw and learned about had been taken from a nearby forest by the family who then had them as a pet. We have additional photos and maybe some more video so if you have any questions or need more photos just shoot me an email!

They were being fed rice and some fruit. At a separate home there was a young, under a year, female Eulemur mongoz tied with rope around her waist which was tied to a table (no cage). She may have been available for sale but I was told she was a pet. I was encouraged to feed her a banana. There was an additional Efr juvenile seen in a village outside of Mitsinjo, with rope tied around its waist that was brought to us because they thought we would like to see it. It was not as stressed as the above mentioned ones. I do not know how/where it was kept or what it was fed. In Ft. Dauphin, the Lemur catta was spotted in a cage on the side of someone's home. There may have been more and I was only walking by so I do not have anymore information about that one. In 2010, we were told that there are many lemurs for sale in Mahajunga. An ex-pat who owned a restaurant in the city talked with us about how often she was approached to purchase lemurs. If she refused, she would be told that the lemur would be eaten because they wouldn't take it all the way back to the forest. She had seen several different species but the only one she could confirm was a species of sifaka.

Something that isn't clear here with your research is what counts as "kept as pets?" What counts as a pet versus non-pet, and what counts as kept (longer-term keeping?) vs not-kept (a few days?...a few years?...something else)? I STRONGLY suggest you clarify what you mean so you will receive more meaningful answers here - especially from those of us who have spent many years in the country and have seen a whole spectrum of possibly "pet keeping" scenarios. Over a 10 year period I haven't seen a ton of clearly domesticated long-term pet lemurs, but I know of MANY restaurants/hotels that have them. I only mentioned two restaurant/hotel scenarios because I knew the lemurs were kept in/right outside the hotel/restaurant permanently (until the lemurs died). In many other hotels I saw lemurs, semi-wild (were not in a cage/tethered), but fed so they stuck around, visited at certain times of the day. The number of lemurs in this more intermittent pet-type setting is much more numerous (on the order of 150-250 lemurs total) than I've mentioned here. I would say I've seen on the order of 10-20 small Malagasy owned and ran restaurants/hotels, 20-30 small/medium foreign owned restaurants/hotels across the island over the 10+ years I've been working/researching/traveling in Madagascar. Multiple lemurs would visit each of these restaurants/hotels. Nosy Be, neighboring islands, and the mainland area across from Nosy Be is a hotbed for this type of activity.The number of pets: permanent, fed, domesticated (they stick around their owners permanently), were raised primarily by people is a lot fewer (three that I can remember).

The indri was free but it was plain it feels lonely and not in an appropriate environment. (Later on, I did quite a lot of work on lemurs and I understood how hard it must have for this vertical clinger to stay at this place where there was few options to move and rest on - unlike the lemurs who are more on quadrupedal posture).I held it for a while. It sort of bit me a little, then it felt secure in my arms like a big baby: it knew I did no mean to harm it. I worked as a tourist guide in October 1997. Our speed boeat was late and I started to look for another one when I was directed to the house of the couple that rented a speed boat and also managed a restaurant. The woman told me that his husband was gone doing some shopping with the speed boat and that they rented it to their client. Meanwhile, I was invited to have lunch which I accepted. It was during that moment that I held the indri in my arms, unique moment as it is hard to find indri as captive.

Home environment with family as a pet. Sleeps with family members. Handled by children. See comments below with regard to how it was kept prior to arriving in this environment.

I have lived in Madagascar for several years and then recently returned after spending more than 10 yrs in the US. This particular lemur was brought to the home of an ex-pat by a Malagasy man attempting to sell the lemur for 100K ariary. The ex-pat has some sort of affiliation with environmental work. He told the salesman that he would take the lemur for 10K ariary or he would call the police. The man gave the lemur for 10K Ar. Apparently the lemur had a rope tied around its waist and it had eroded down to the skin. The ex-pat approached some environmental group/authority (I don't know who) who said that the lemur was too domesticated to go back into the wild. As a result, they kept the lemur as a house pet. Don't know the gender. Lemur lives freely in the house and sleep with the family. Will gently bite if agitated. Otherwise, lemur is apparently affectionate with humans and is often handled by children. This family has lived in Madagascar for more than a decade and plans to remain in M/scar indefinitely.

other_comments: Le propriétaire est malgache, chef d'un groupe d'agent de sécurité (T.V.H.F.B.), il pense sauver ces animaux, il les récupère sur les marchés pour éviter qu'ils ne soient mangés.Tous enfermés dans une cage étroite, placée dans une ruelle, la cage est ouverte de temps en temps. Le risque d'hybridation est important. L'organisation sociale n'est pas respectée, certains individus peuvent très être agressifs avec d'autres. Il n'est pas informé des risques de cette captivité et que cela nuit à la conservation.Les animaux sont nourris à la banane principalement, il y a très peu de diversité dans les repas. Sujet très difficile à aborder vue la place de cette personne.

The bamboo lemur at the resort on Ile Aux Nattes was certainly a free spirit. I think it was raised by the owner as a baby. It was not in a cage or mistreated in any way. In fact, it routinely came around during lunch and dinner and jumped around. It had the most character of any animal I've seen. We chased it around for awhile but we were no match and it stayed the night in the room. Very entertaining and cool.

environment_name: Ony Hotel at Lac Rasoamasay, Pangalanes Canal
other_comments:
Translocated free-ranging lemurs near to and owned by Ony Hotel. The Malagasy owners of the hotel were in the early stages of setting up what they intended to be a multi-species lemur park to rival that of Palmarium further up the canal. At the time they had only these newly acquired black-and-white ruffed lemurs, at least two of them (as pictured) but probably four or five in total if I remember correctly.

other_comments: I just came back from vacation in Madagascar, there I went on a mangrove/fishing village excursion and my paddler showed me around the village where I saw the lemurs in a house. I took pictures with my phone to have the coordinate to report them when back home. I didn't mention this to the guide so he wouldn't alert the owners, I never saw the owners, we were just walking around the village. After seeing a lot of lemurs in the wild it was heartbreaking seeing those two lemurs captive and looking so sad and sick, those are not healthy lemurs. Please rescue them. Again, the coordinates are 20.30 S, 44.27 E.
lemur_sex_details: They look sad and sick, it was heartbreaking. They are in a dirty place, I don't know if they were tied.
lemur_additional_details: I don't know but I took pictures if you want, and from my phone I got the coordinates of the place, it's in Betania (fishing village) coordinates 20.30 S, 44.27 E.
lemur_health_details: the look sad, eyes lifeless.

lemur_purpose_other:
The owner keeps the lemur as his "little friend", and tries to impress tourists/visitors with it. But most time, the lemur just sits behind the restaurant alone. 

(seen in March 2017, by the way, but this wasn't an option to choose )
lemur_health_details: Looks rather healthy, but fur could be more tight, especially the tail seemed to have some skin issues. No visible injuries from the leash.
other_comments: The lemur has been bought approximately 2 years ago, and since then has been staying at Maewa hotel. Most time he is kept right behind the hotel on wooden planks (earlier nearby the entry to the beach) on a short leash, allowing him only to walk 2 meteres around. Everyone can access the area easily, most tourists take pictures if they recognize it's a lemur. If the owner is there, he shows around the lemur and "walks him out" on the leash or let the lemur sit on his shoulder.
lemur_sex_details: The next protected area is Andranomena national park (or still reserve integrale?) which struggles against wood cutting and lemur thieves, and Kirindy reserve, which is rather well protected.
owner_wealthy_cont: It's the French hotel owner who bought and keeps the lemur.
lemur_food: Yes, mainly with dry dog food and fruits.

lemur_purpose_money: lemurs are attracted to hotels which have a lemur
other_comments: We saw another captive lemur in Andasibe in a restaurant.  It was tied up.  The local tourist guide took us there in 2011
